semantic_title: Two or More Diagnoses Equally Meeting Principal Diagnosis Definition - Equal Criteria Sequencing Rules
section_path: Section II > Selection of Principal Diagnosis > C. Two or more diagnoses that equally meet the definition for principal diagnosis

content.full_text: In the unusual instance when two or more diagnoses equally meet the criteria for principal diagnosis as determined by the circumstances of admission, diagnostic workup and/or therapy provided, and the Alphabetic Index, Tabular List, or another coding guidelines does not provide sequencing direction, any one of the diagnoses may be sequenced first. (Evidence: pg no: 108, L109-L111)
content.summary: Guidelines for rare situations where multiple diagnoses equally meet principal diagnosis criteria and no specific sequencing guidance exists (Evidence: pg no: 108, L109-L111)
key_concepts: Unusual instance of truly equal principal diagnosis criteria (Evidence: pg no: 108, L109-L110)
Equality determined by admission circumstances, workup, and therapy (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110)
No sequencing direction from coding resources (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110-L111)
Any diagnosis may be sequenced first in such cases (Evidence: pg no: 108, L111)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Unusual instance when diagnoses equally meet principal diagnosis criteria (Evidence: pg no: 108, L109-L110)
detailed_rules.explanation: This situation is rare and requires that multiple diagnoses truly meet the principal diagnosis definition equally based on all clinical factors (Evidence: pg no: 108, L109-L110)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Equality determined by admission circumstances, diagnostic workup, and therapy provided (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110)
detailed_rules.explanation: All clinical factors must support equal significance of the diagnoses for principal diagnosis consideration (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Alphabetic Index, Tabular List, or coding guidelines provide no sequencing direction (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110-L111)
detailed_rules.explanation: This rule only applies when official coding resources do not provide specific guidance on sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 108, L110-L111)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Any one of the diagnoses may be sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 108, L111)
detailed_rules.explanation: When all criteria are met for equal consideration, the coder has flexibility in sequencing choice (Evidence: pg no: 108, L111)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify multiple diagnoses potentially meeting principal diagnosis criteria
Step 2: Evaluate admission circumstances for each diagnosis
Step 3: Review diagnostic workup significance for each condition
Step 4: Assess therapy provided for each condition
Step 5: Consult Alphabetic Index and Tabular List for sequencing guidance
Step 6: Review coding guidelines for specific direction
Step 7: If truly equal and no guidance exists, select any diagnosis as principal

code_categories_mentioned: Any diagnostic codes that could equally meet principal diagnosis criteria

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted with simultaneous acute myocardial infarction and acute stroke, both requiring equal intensive treatment
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient found down, brought to ED. Simultaneous acute MI and acute stroke diagnosed. Equal intensive treatment provided for both conditions with cardiology and neurology teams.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify conditions (acute MI, acute stroke)
Step 2: Evaluate admission circumstances (both conditions prompted admission)
Step 3: Review diagnostic workup (equal significance for both)
Step 4: Assess therapy (intensive treatment for both)
Step 5: Check coding guidance (no specific sequencing direction)
Step 6: Apply equal criteria rule - either may be principal
